Using predicate logic, prove or disprove the following statement:

For all real numbers x, if x is greater than 3, then 2x is greater than 6.
message_2:
To prove the statement using predicate logic, we will use the following notation:

∀x (P(x) → Q(x))

where P(x) represents "x is greater than 3" and Q(x) represents "2x is greater than 6".

Now, let's assume P(x) is true, i.e., x > 3. We need to show that Q(x) is also true, i.e., 2x > 6.

If x > 3, then multiplying both sides of the inequality by 2 (since 2 is a positive number, the inequality sign remains the same) gives:

2x > 6

So, if P(x) is true, then Q(x) is also true. Therefore, the statement is true:

∀x (x > 3 → 2x > 6)
